content.text: • Place the metre ruler on the pivot at the 50.0 cm mark with its scale facing upwards
• Place the object Q with its centre on the metre ruler at the 90.0 cm mark
Record the distance \(y\) from the centre of Q to the 100.0 cm end of the ruler
Measure, and record in Table 1.1, the distance \(x\) from the centre of P to the zero end of the ruler. Record the weight \(P\)
Repeat the steps above, using loads of weight \(P = 3.0 \text{N}, 4.0 \text{N}, 5.0 \text{N}\) and \(6.0 \text{N}\)
Record all the values of \(P\) and \(x\) in Table 1.1. Ensure that the position of object Q on the metre ruler does **not** change
• Place a load P of weight \(P = 2.0 \text{N}\) on the metre ruler
• Adjust the position of P so that the metre ruler is as near as possible to being balanced
Plot a graph of \(P / \mathsf{N}\) (y-axis) against \(x / \mathsf{cm}\) (x-axis)
Draw the best-fit line
Use the graph to find the value of \(x\) required to balance the ruler when \(P = 3.5 \text{N}\)
Show clearly on the graph how you determined the value of \(x\)
In this experiment, you will investigate the balancing of a metre ruler
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
Use the thermometer to measure the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\)
Pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. Place the thermometer in the hot water in the beaker
Record in Table 2.1 the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0\). Immediately start the stop-watch
Continue recording the temperature in Table 2.1 at 30 s intervals until you have seven sets of readings
Complete the column headings in Table 2.1
Calculate the decrease in temperature \(\Delta \theta\) between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
\(\Delta \theta =\)
Calculate the average rate of cooling \(R\) of the water using the equation \(R = \frac{\Delta \theta}{\Delta t}\),
where \(\Delta t = 180 \text{s}\). Include the unit
R =
Suggest **one** change to the experiment that you could make to test the statement
Suggest how to display the results to make it easier to see the trend in the rate of cooling
A student states that the average rate of cooling of the water decreases as the temperature comes nearer to room temperature
Explain briefly why it is good practice to read the thermometer scale at right angles
In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of water
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1
Draw a line across the ray-trace sheet supplied, approximately in the middle. Label the line \(\mathbf{PQ}\)
· Place the transparent block, largest face down, with the straight side on the line \(\mathbf{PQ}\) and the curved side below the line
· Draw round the outline of the block. Label the ends of the straight side of the block \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\)
· Remove the block and draw the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\) through the centre of \(\mathbf{AB}\). Continue the normal so that it passes through the curved side of the block
· Label the point \(\mathbf{C}\) where the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\) crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Draw the line \(\mathbf{DC}\) at an angle \(i = 30^{\circ}\) to the normal, as shown in Fig. 3.1
Place the paper on the pin board
Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\), on line \(\mathbf{DC}\) at a suitable distance apart for this experiment

Replace the block and look from the position of the eye shown in Fig. 3.1 to observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) through side \(\mathbf{AB}\) of the block. Adjust your line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) appear one behind the other

Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\), between your eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\), \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other
Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\), \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\), \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\)
Remove the block and the pins
Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). Continue the line to \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Label \(\mathbf{E}\), the end of the line furthest from \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Measure the acute angle \(\theta\) between the line \(\mathbf{NL}\) and the line \(\mathbf{CE}\). (An acute angle is less than \(90^{\circ}\).)
State one precaution that you take to produce an accurate ray trace
Place the transparent block on the ray-trace sheet in the position shown in Fig. 3.2
· Replace pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line \(\mathbf{DC}\) in the same positions used in \((\mathbf{b})\)

· Observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through the curved side of the block. Adjust your line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other

· Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\), between your eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_5\), \(\mathsf{P}_6\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other
· Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\)
Remove the block and the pins
· Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_5\) and \(\mathsf{P}_6\). Continue the line to \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Label \(\mathbf{F}\), the end of the line furthest from \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Measure the acute angle \(\theta\) between the line \(\mathbf{NL}\) and the line \(\mathbf{CF}\). (An acute angle is less than \(90^{\circ}\).)
Tie your ray-trace sheet into this question booklet between pages 8 and 9
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light using a semicircular transparent block
Carry out the following instructions using the separate ray-trace sheet provided. You may refer to Fig. 3.1 and Fig. 3.2 for guidance
Fig. 3.1
A student investigates the change in resistance of a lamp filament when the current in the lamp is increased
The following apparatus is available:
· a power supply
· a low-voltage filament lamp
· an ammeter
· a voltmeter
· connecting wires
Other apparatus normally found in a school laboratory is also available
Plan an experiment to investigate the change in resistance of the lamp filament when the current in the lamp is increased
Resistance \(R\) is given by the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\) , where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the lamp and \(I\) is the current in the lamp
You are **not** required to do this investigation
You should:
· draw a diagram of the circuit used
· explain briefly how to do the investigation, including how to change the current
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
· explain how to use your readings to reach a conclusion
